awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Evolution and Dynamics of the Deep Waters in the Arctic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
In stark contrast to the shallower regions of the Arctic Ocean, where significant warming and freshening have been observed, the deepest waters are isolated vertically by strong stratification and laterally by ocean ridges; parts of the deep Arctic Ocean have been effectively inaccessible to new water influxes for hundreds of years. As such, the properties of these water masses can be used as valuable markers of past climate, while future changes to them would be compelling signals of an Arctic climate in transition. This proposal seeks to investigate the origins and history of the deepest waters through analysis of existing data sets and idealized numerical modeling.  Such understanding is essential to understand how the deep waters of the Arctic Ocean participate in climate change.  

This project will address several interrelated observational and dynamical questions: What constrains the evolution of heat and salt in the deep water? How is the deep water influenced by the rest of the Arctic Ocean? What past ocean conditions and mechanisms allowed for the formation of the deep water, and what climate shift may have prompted an end to ventilation of the bottom waters? These aspects of the climate system will be investigated by dynamical process studies constrained by analyses of recent ocean measurements from moored instruments and icebreaker surveys.

This project comprises an integrated research, education, and outreach program that implements a tiered mentoring approach to provide experience in Arctic climate research for scholars from high school to postdoctoral level. Education and outreach integrates with Yale University?s well-established Pathways to Science infrastructure: high school students (over half of whom are from traditionally underrepresented groups) will be introduced to Arctic climate science through lectures and laboratory demonstrations, while graduate students will receive teaching and mentoring experience. The project generates opportunities for independent climate research appropriate to a range of skillsets and interests, with high school students being recruited concurrently with undergraduate students for summer research internships. Through an international partnership with the University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), undergraduate and graduate students will be introduced to the Arctic environment, learning fundamental concepts of the Arctic climate system through lectures and participating in fieldwork. Students will deploy innovative Arctic instrumentation in the fjords of Svalbard and will then process and interpret the measurements. In collaboration with the Yale Climate and Energy Institute (YCEI) and the International Arctic Science Committee, an international workshop, motivated by the central theme of the proposed research, will bring together researchers across a range of disciplines (including anthropologists, paleoceanographers and contemporary climate scientists) to explore the important relationships between culture and Arctic climate change over the past millennia.

por.por_cntn:
The research has developed an integrated picture of a host of dynamical and thermodynamical processes in an Arctic Ocean undergoing significant change. We have demonstrated that there has been a doubling of ocean heat content in the Arctic Ocean's Canada Basin over the past three decades; the release of this heat would be critical to the overlying sea-ice pack. Our findings describing the source for the heat increase reveal the influence of Arctic sea-ice losses at the basin margins and subsequent solar warming in these regions. Our results suggest there may be an upper limit on the amount of deep-ocean heat that can be stored, and this must be accounted for in future predictions of Arctic climate.

Other findings related to Arctic Ocean heat transport stem from our application of theoretical concepts to interpret ocean observations of temperature and salinity layers which are a manifestation of double-diffusive convection, a process by which heat and salt are transported in the Arctic Ocean. Our analysis describing the physics and origins of the ocean layers sheds light on how heat transport in the Arctic Ocean will change under different scenarios of relatively warm and salty Atlantic Water entering the Arctic Ocean. We have mapped and characterized these layers across the Arctic Ocean, showing that they are only present where mixing by the winds and tides (i.e., turbulent mixing) is weak. We have shown explicitly that there is a critical level of turbulence in the Arctic Ocean above which heat transport from the Atlantic Water will no longer be via double diffusion. This is an important predictive result as wind-driven Arctic Ocean mixing increases with continued sea-ice losses.

A final key outcome relates to our development of a new analytical approach to interpret data and build up a first-order picture of mixing, heat fluxes and circulation in the relatively unexplored deep Canada Basin waters. Little has been known about the deepest Arctic Ocean currents because flows are too slow there to be measured by standard instrumentation. The method we have developed to quantify the circulation in the deep Arctic Ocean has broad applications for characterizing deep-ocean dynamics elsewhere, where velocities are typically much weaker than the upper-ocean flows.

In sum, through characterization and development of constraints on ocean heat transport and storage, circulation and energetics, and implications of sea-ice loss to ocean structure, our results allow for better projections of the ocean, sea-ice and climate state in the coming years and decades.

The research has involved graduate and undergraduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, including student and postdoc participation in Arctic field expeditions. Outreach engaged high-school students (underrepresented minorities, and first generation in their families to attend college) in the STEM fields through the Pathways to Science program. During three summers, an Earth Science module (Physics of the Atmosphere & Oceans: From the Tropics to the Arctic) was developed and presented to high-school students staying on Yale campus. A significant component involved hands-on laboratory fluid dynamics experiments. Other outreach activities included a public Climate Day held at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History; an interdisciplinary, international workshop (Culture and Climate in the Arctic) on an integrated examination of Arctic anthropology, and past and contemporary Arctic climate; tutorial presentations and development of laboratory demonstrations for the NSF Forum for Arctic Modeling and Observational Synthesis (FAMOS) school for researchers new to the Arctic; and a graduate student field class in Alaska and the Yukon to study glaciers, lakes and regional geology and ecology.
